pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:0.5: 9. The second training rule on what is set aside
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.2: a certain man said to another man,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.3: “I’m going to give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.6: An alms-collecting monk heard that conversation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.7: He then went to Upananda the Sakyan and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.9: In such-and-such a place I heard two men telling each other
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.10: that they’re each going to give you robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.14: Upananda then went to those men and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.15: “Is it true that you want to give me robe-cloth?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.17: that’s just what we were thinking.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.18: “If that’s the case, then give me such-and-such robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.19: For what’s the point of giving robe-cloth that I won’t use?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.20: Those men complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.21: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.22: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.23: How could Venerable Upananda come to us and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited by us to do so?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.24: The monks heard the complaints of those men,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.25: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.26: “How could Venerable Upananda go to householders and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited to do so?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.27: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.28: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.32: “Foolish man, people who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.35: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.36.1: ‘If two male or female householders have set aside separate robe funds for an unrelated monk, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.37: “With these separate robe funds we’ll buy separate robe-cloths and give them to monk so-and-so;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.38: and if that monk, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.39: “Please put these separate robe funds together to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.40: and he does so because he wants something fine, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.2: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, they want to give to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.6: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.8: any men who live at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.10: any women who live at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.12: money, gold, pearls, gems, corals, crystals, cloth, thread, or cotton wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.14: with that which is at their disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.20: the monk the robe funds have been set aside for.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.22: they have not said beforehand: “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth can we buy for you?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.24: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.25: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.26: please make it long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.28: that which is at their disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.30: long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.36: two people supplying him with one robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.38: wanting something good, wanting something expensive.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.39: If those householders buy robe-cloth that is long, wide, closely woven, or soft because of his statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.40: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.41: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.42: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.43: (To be expanded as in [Bu Np 1:3.2.5](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5)–Bu Np 1:3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.44: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received after going to unrelated householders and saying what kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited, is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.45: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.48: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.49.1: If the householders are unrelated and he perceives them as such, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.50: If the householders are unrelated, but he is unsure of it, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.51: If the householders are unrelated, but he perceives them as related, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.52: If the householders are related, but he perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.53: If the householders are related, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.54: If the householders are related and he perceives them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.57: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.58: if it is for the benefit of another;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.59: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.60: if the householders wish to buy something expensive, but he has them buy something inexpensive;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.62: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.63: The second training rule on what is set aside, the ninth, is finished.
